subject: test generation as a tool for coverage
msgSnippet: Test generators are not really geared for functional *black* box testing, I agree, but they can be excellent for *white* box efforts. Test generators can help

Test generators are not really geared for functional *black* box testing, =
I agree, but they can be excellent for *white* box efforts.

Test generator=
s can help build tests to achieve 100% path, branch and statement coverage.=
..  This can help identify impossible paths in your code, as well as rare p=
aths that lead to exceptions (such as null pointers).

andrew f



  ----- =
Original Message ----- 
  From: Vladimir Bossicard 
  To: junit@yahoogroups=
.com 
  Sent: Tuesday, March 19, 2002 1:18 PM
  Subject: Re: [junit] RE: Is=
 there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?


  Starting a new project =
of maintaining one are two different problems.
  The XP 'test-first' method=
 is well suited for a new project, but can be
  dangerous is applied blindl=
y to an already developped project.

     > On a larger project, I agree th=
at the initial benefit is reduced, but
     > there is a tangible benefit o=
f having the initial unit test
     > *structure* in place.

       I don't=
 think that the time needed to generate stubs for a small or
  large projec=
t make the difference (if it's only an empty TestCase per
  class + AllTest=
s.java, maybe a couple of seconds).  The good think is
  that you're showin=
g the way to go.  The developers will have someting to
  work on immediatel=
y.

     > 2. As for JTest, it will do even something else for you, which i=
s to
     > come up (through reflection
     > and some other techniques) w=
ith a basic set of unit tests that can be
     > manually augmented later

=

  I always have problem with tools that generate "tests" for your code.
  =
But as I don't know JTest, take my comment as general.

  Writing tests is =
verifying what the class _must_ do and not what the
  class _is_ doing.  Be=
cause the tool has normally no way of guessing what
  the class must do, it=
 tests its actual behaviour.  To my opinion, these
  "tests" do not help yo=
u to find bugs (in general), but can be seen as a
  "safety net" (because o=
nce generated, they should all pass).  If one of
  these tests failes after=
 adding a feature, it tells you that you changed
  the behaviour of your ap=
plication.  It's up to you then to review the
  "test" and see if it's stil=
l accurate.  But maybe JTest acts differently.

  -Vladimir

  -- 
  Vladim=
ir Bossicard
